description: Achene with wing; indicates wing.
One-seeded indehiscent dry fruit; pericarp not fused to seed coat.
Asteraceae-type achene (often with pappus; technically an achene from an inferior ovary).
Fruit enclosed by persistent perianth (often in Nyctaginaceae); typically indehiscent.
notes: Can be a dispersal unit conceptually.

description: Berry-like fruit with woody rind; interior fleshy.
Rare term indicating fruit/seed with prominent aril; often implies fleshy reward around seeds.
Pomegranate-type; many arillate seeds within.
True berry; typically fleshy pericarp.
Cactus fruit term; usually fleshy.
Rare term used for fleshy seed-coat derived structures; overlaps with sarcotesta concepts.
Explicit fleshy berry; strong cue.
Citrus-type berry; typically fleshy.
Hard-rinded berry; interior fleshy.
Explicit pulpy berry; strong cue.
Describes fused carpels (syncarpous gynoecium); may be applied to many fruit forms.
notes: Modifier, not a standalone fruit type.

description: General dry dehiscent fruit formed from â‰¥2 carpels; opens to release seeds.
Describes opening by a transverse lid (circumscissile dehiscence).
Capsule subtype: circumscissile; synonymous with pyxis in many floras.
Describes capsule opening along the locules (loculicidal dehiscence).
Capsule subtype: loculicidal dehiscence.
Describes opening by pores/pori (poricidal dehiscence).
Capsule subtype: poricidal opening.
Circumscissile capsule (lid-like opening).
Describes capsule opening along septa (septicidal dehiscence).
Capsule subtype: septicidal dehiscence.
Brassicaceae-type short silique; capsule-like with replum.
notes: Often treated as a capsule subtype.

description: Brassicaceae-type long capsule-like fruit; dehisces leaving a replum.
notes: Often treated as a capsule subtype.

description: Grass grain; indehiscent dry fruit with pericarp fused to seed coat.
Common-language descriptor for caryopsis-like fruits (esp. Poaceae).
Aggregate drupe descriptor; usually fleshy.
Aggregate of drupes/drupelets; commonly fleshy.
Drupe; typically fleshy with stony endocarp.
Small drupe; often used in aggregate/etaerio contexts.
notes: Often a descriptor rather than a separate type.

description: Technical term for aggregate of drupelets; commonly fleshy.
Drupe-like fruit; term used when development/origin deviates from a classic drupe.
Common-language term for drupes; fleshy reward cue.
Dry dehiscent fruit from a single carpel; opens along one suture.
Gymnosperm cone (strobilus); not a true fruit; may be woody or fleshy.
notes: Include for matching gymnosperm reproductive terms.

description: Female cone; term used in some gymnosperm descriptions.
Male cone; term used in some gymnosperm descriptions.
Female (seed) cone; bears naked seeds.
notes: Not a fruit; dispersal handled by seed traits.

description: Pollen (male) cone; not a fruit but appears in reproductive descriptions.
Ovulate cone; not a true fruit; bears naked seeds on cone scales.
Plural of strobilus; include for keyword recall.
Gymnosperm cone (strobilus); not a true fruit.
Fleshy cone; gymnosperm analogue to fleshy fruits (e.g., junipers).
Berry-like cone (Juniperus); fleshy reward analogue.
notes: Not a true fruit, but acts like a fleshy reward.

description: Juniper 'berry' (fleshy cone); fleshy reward analogue.
notes: Not a true fruit, but acts like a fleshy reward.

description: Fabaceae-type pod; typically dehiscent along two sutures (but can vary).
Segmented legume breaking into one-seeded units (often indehiscent segments).
Colloquial term often used for legume-like fruits; also used loosely outside Fabaceae.
Nut with wings; indicates wing.
Nut: hard pericarp; structural protection cue.
notes: Also a fruit type; kept for protective_tissue inference.

description: Small nut; common descriptor in Lamiaceae/Boraginaceae contexts.
Apple-type pome term used in some datasets/floras.
Pome (accessory fruit); typically fleshy.
Winged indehiscent dry fruit; commonly indicates winged dispersal unit.
Plural; winged dispersal unit.
Samara-like; indicates winged dispersal unit.
Samara explicitly described as winged; indicates wing.
Lamiaceae term sometimes used for a 4-mericarps splitting fruit (related to carcerulus).
notes: Mapping varies; commonly treated as splitting into nutlets.

description: Schizocarp of Lamiaceae sometimes called carcerulus; splits into nutlets/mericarps.
Unit/segment of a regma-type schizocarp (often 1-seeded).
Apiaceae-type schizocarp splitting into two mericarps.
One-seeded segment/unit resulting from schizocarp splitting.
Euphorbiaceae-type schizocarp splitting elastically into cocci/mericarps.
Dry fruit that splits into indehiscent one-seeded units (mericarps) at maturity.
Multiple fruit from inflorescence; often fleshy.
Fig-type multiple fruit; typically fleshy.
Small, thin-walled, bladdery indehiscent fruit; achene-like in many floras.
Alate = winged; often used for winged fruits/seeds.
Wing present on fruit/seed; anemochory cue.
Winged (general); often refers to wings on fruit/seed.
notes: Ambiguous if applied to leaves/stems; use context if possible.

description: Fruit with wing; indicates wing.
Seed with wing; indicates wing.
Awn (bristle) may aid wind dispersal and/or attachment; ambiguous.
notes: Awns can also aid epizoochory; consider context.

description: Awned diaspores; bristle-like appendages.
Tuft of hairs on seed; aids wind dispersal.
Tufted hairs (coma) on seed; aids wind dispersal.
Feathery hairs/bristles; can indicate plume/pappus.
Having a pappus; wind dispersal cue.
Bristles/hairs (often Asteraceae) aiding wind dispersal.
Plumed/feathery hairs aiding wind dispersal.
Feathery/plumose hairs aiding wind dispersal.
Hairs on seeds; can function like coma/pappus.
notes: Could be general pubescence; use context.

description: Often used for comose seeds; may indicate wind-dispersal hairs.
General phrase for coma/pappus-like hair tuft.
Fleshy seed appendage (often vertebrate reward).
notes: Some small arils can be ant-related; consider context.

description: Seeds with aril; strong cue for fleshy reward.
Explicit aril around seed; strong cue for fleshy reward.
Aril-like outgrowth; cue for fleshy reward.
Edible pulp around seeds; cue for vertebrate reward.
Describes fruit/seed covering as fleshy; strong cue for vertebrate reward.
Explicitly states fruit is fleshy; strong cue for vertebrate reward.
Fleshy mesocarp; cue for vertebrate reward.
Fleshy pericarp; cue for vertebrate reward.
Fleshy testa/sarcotesta; cue for fleshy reward.
Fleshy testa; cue for fleshy reward.
Juicy fruit tissue; cue for fleshy reward.
Explicitly juicy fruit; cue for fleshy reward.
Pulpy fruit tissue; strong cue for fleshy reward.
Explicitly pulpy fruit; strong cue for fleshy reward.
Fleshy seed coat layer; cue for fleshy reward.
Phrase indicating aril around seed; cue for fleshy reward.
Succulent fruit tissue; cue for fleshy reward.
Explicitly succulent fruit; cue for fleshy reward.
Sweet pulp around seeds; cue for vertebrate reward.
Barbed structures aiding attachment.
Barbs aiding attachment.
Burr-like fruiting unit; classic epizoochory.
Burr-like; classic epizoochory.
Burrs; classic epizoochory.
Clings to fur/clothing; indicates attachment structures.
Barbed bristles aiding attachment.
Barbed bristles aiding attachment.
Hooked structures aiding attachment to fur/feathers.
Hook structures aiding attachment.
Backward-pointing barbs/spines; often attachment.
Spines; may indicate attachment when on diaspore.
notes: Can also be defensive; use context.

description: Spines may aid attachment when on fruits/bracts.
notes: Can also be defensive; use context.

description: Hooked (uncinate) bristles/spines; attachment.
Adhesive surface aiding attachment.
Glutinous/sticky surface aiding adhesion.
Gummy/sticky coating; adhesion cue.
Mucilage; potentially sticky when wet; context needed.
Mucilage present; can indicate stickiness when wet; context needed.
Resinous/sticky exudate may aid adhesion.
Sticky surface aiding adhesion to animals/substrates.
Explicitly sticky seeds; adhesion cue.
Viscid (sticky) surface aiding adhesion.
Explicitly viscid seeds; adhesion cue.
Explicit ant dispersal mention; suggests ant-attracting reward.
Micropylar appendage; often lipid-rich and ant-attracting.
Having a caruncle; often ant-related.
Lipid-rich seed appendage attracting ants (myrmecochory).
Explicit ant-dispersal term; often implies ant-attracting reward.
Air chambers; may aid flotation.
Air-filled cavities; may aid flotation.
Bladdery/inflated; can aid flotation.
notes: Also used for utricles; context needed.

description: Explicitly buoyant; indicates floating dispersal potential.
Pericarp described as buoyant; hydrochory cue.
Corky tissues often aid flotation; hydrochory cue.
Fibrous pericarp can aid flotation (coconut-like).
Float/floatation mention; hydrochory cue.
Explicitly floats; hydrochory cue.
Explicitly floats; hydrochory cue.
Inflated fruit/pericarp; may aid flotation and/or wind; context needed.
Spongy tissues often aid flotation; hydrochory cue.
Ballistic seed ejection; autochory.
Catapult-like ejection; ballistic cue.
Elastic tension causes seed ejection.
Explosive fruiting; often ballistic dispersal.
Explosive opening ejects seeds; ballistic dispersal.
Forceful opening ejects seeds.
Explicit seed ejection; ballistic cue.
Explicit ejection of seeds; ballistic cue.
Acorn: nut-like; structural protection cue.
Leathery (coriaceous) seed coat; structural protection.
Fibrous endocarp; protection (and sometimes flotation).
notes: May overlap buoyancy in some taxa.

description: Hard seed coat; structural protection.
Hard seed coat; structural protection.
Leathery fruit wall; structural protection.
Lignified endocarp; protection.
Sclerified (hardened) pericarp; protection.
Shell-like covering; protection.
Stone/endocarp stone mention; protection cue.
notes: Context needed: could refer to stones in soil.

description: Stony endocarp; strong protection.
Thick seed coat; structural protection.
Thick seed coat; structural protection.
Thick fruit wall; structural protection.
Woody inner fruit wall; strong protection (stone fruits).
Descriptor phrase indicating accessory tissues in the fruit.
notes: Useful phrase match; very often correlate with fleshy fruits but not always.

description: Descriptor phrase indicating aggregate fruiting structure.
notes: Useful phrase match; does not itself imply a dispersal trait.

description: Descriptor phrase indicating multiple/compound fruiting structure.
notes: Useful phrase match; ambiguous aggregate vs multiple.

description: General descriptor: fruiting structure derived from multiple flowers (infructescence).
